Sometimes I'm amazed what I overlook in reading articles. I was rereading the CRN article last Feb about Dell cancelling the VMW GTM agreement at once (2 years before official expiration) after the Broadcom acquisition. It states that the Dell channel accounting for 40% of VMW sales, that is $7 billion! Subsequently Dell and NTNX cozied up and started working together. Now, not all that $5b is going to flow to NTNX, of course, but even small portion would be a meaningful amount for NTNX, particularly when you combine that with a recent article referring research that half of VMW customers weigh alternatives. So you have now the demand side cratering as well as the 'supply' (GTM channel) side to stop pushing VMW---that's a double whammy. Dell may even turn to NTNX as VxRail replacement, just like CSCO terminated HyperFlex. Maybe someone with more knowledge on product strategy level can chime in what is realistic?

Dippie re: regulatory approval for takeover of NTNX, you mentioned a concern that an acquisition of NTNX might be blocked due to the difficulty of getting regulatory approval. I'm sure you have seen the article from Silicon Angle. Note that the graphic includes a title "Alternatives to VMWare respond in droves".  I see 10 competitors in the space, which doesn't even include Nutanix. Approval wouldn't be a problem IMO. This is not an AT&T and T-Mobile situation. Regardless, I still don't see an acquisition in the cards until Nutanix establishes a stronger execution pattern, which would justify a higher premium.

Jackie is not off base with ONE possibility in her last post (9:30am Central). How executives manage the Street is critical to their long term approach to potential stock price appreciation. They should tamp down exuberance whether it's due to the price itself heating up or analysts' expectations. Under guide and over perform is good strategy. However, if it was due to something fundamentally altering product acceptance in the industry that's a whole other ballgame. You fundamentalists can better address that than I.

Just reading through the Generation Investment Management filing, the filing was triggered because of sales activity on 7/24. I suspect that was the last day they sold. The price started to recover right after that. It looks like they were selling from 7/11 to 7/24. So, it certainly does explain the decline in share price we saw during that time. These were not sales prior to 6/30. They have been selling over previous quarters, so my guess is these were planned sales to scale out. Maybe they are done selling and wanted to rebalance. I don't know. It could also be that they realize this is Bain's show now. Is it just a mere coincidence that Generation completes their sales by 7/24 and Bain gets their shares on 7/29? Interesting, don't you think? I also find it strange that the short interest as of the last report was 4,982,111. Generation sold 4,619,101 shares. Did someone cover?

Generation Investment Management filed their 13G/A form today showing they reduced their holdings to 12,530,227 shares. This represents a reduction of 4,619,101 shares or 26.77% of what they had previously reported.
